lessonOverview.title: Unit 4 - Lesson 1
structures: B: Yes, he/she is. / No, he/she isn’t.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six jobs (doctor, chef, teacher, nurse, bus driver, student) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Show flashcards of jobs (doctor, chef, nurse, etc.). Say each word and ask students to repeat and match with pictures in the SB.
stretchStrategies: Mini Interview Role-play – Stronger students create and perform short dialogues interviewing each other about jobs. Add follow-ups like:
B: No, he isn’t. He’s a bus driver. He loves driving kids to school.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can say simple statements about people's jobs using "He's/She's a..." / "He/She isn't a..." and ask and answer simple questions using "Is he/she a...?" and "Yes, he/she is." / "No, he/she isn't."
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Show a picture. Ask: “Is he a teacher?” Students answer “Yes, he is.” or “No, he isn’t.” Practise with role-play cards.
stretchStrategies: Mini Interview Role-play – Stronger students create and perform short dialogues interviewing each other about jobs. Add follow-ups like:
B: No, he isn’t. He’s a bus driver. He loves driving kids to school.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “He’s/She’s a ___.” / “He/She isn’t a ___.” and ask and answer using “Is he/she a ___?” / “Yes, he/she is.” / “No, he/she isn’t.” to talk about people’s jobs.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) On the board: “He’s a ___.” / “She isn’t a ___.” Drill positive and negative examples. Students take turns asking and answering in pairs.
stretchStrategies: Mini Interview Role-play – Stronger students create and perform short dialogues interviewing each other about jobs. Add follow-ups like:
B: No, he isn’t. He’s a bus driver. He loves driving kids to school.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
